Ford hasn't kept the upcoming F-150 Lightning a secret, evidenced by the company's million-pound towing stunt from 2019. The Lightning shares much of the regular F-150's body and cabin but swaps that truck's gasoline-powered V-6 and V-8 engine options for a pair of electric motors and one of two different battery packs. The Standard-Range battery is said to deliver up to 230 miles per charge and the Extended-Range juice pack is aiming for 300 miles. But by the time the 2022 F-150 Lightning reaches the market, it won't be the only all-electric pickup truck. GMC's Hummer EV SUT is close to its launch, and a rival truck from upstart Rivian may also beat Ford to the punch. Neither of those trucks, however, have the strength of the F-150 name behind them, and the electric version of America's favorite truck will surely be an impressive piece when it goes on sale sometime in spring 2022.

Why
Why

@will.dornon yes, but still, why hasn't anyone taken up this opportunity??? Why hasn't Hewlett-Packard (HP), or Lenovo, or LG, or any other manufacturer that makes computers, seized this opportunity to make a massive amount of profit in the current market? I'm telling you, whether we like it or not, they're INTENTIONALLY limiting the production of their vehicles at this point, which artificially drives up the demand for them, which also means they can sell them for two to three times what they're actually worth... hate to sound like a conspiracy theorist, but given the circumstances in this country right now, it's the most logical explanation I can come up with...
@will.dornon plus, it means they can count out dealerships on part of the profit, eliminating the middle-man (at least partially) at the same time.

@unashamed_obs I don’t really know, they don’t really have an incentive to help automakers unless paid to do so, and the automakers I assume don’t want to do that because they know they will bounce right back.

@will.dornon I don't honestly know either man, but I will say that I hope I'm wrong on the situation. I hope there is a legitimate reason that things are being held up, and that it will be resolved in the near future, so that we can go back to the way things were. But unfortunately, I don't have a lot of faith in big companies and corporations these days, as they've proven time and time again that they're mostly just money hungry executives, and that they really don't care about their constituents.
